steps.title: You Have All the Pieces
steps.narration: You've learned to ask deep questions. You've learned to see and analyze data. You've learned to build real things. Now it's time to put it all together and solve a real problem.

steps.title: Start with Questions
steps.narration: Every solution starts with understanding. Go six levels deep to truly understand the problem. Don't jump to solutions‚Äîunderstand the root causes first.

steps.title: Gather Data
steps.narration: Collect information about your problem. What resources exist? What do people say? What specific data would help? Organize what you find and look for patterns.

steps.title: Find Insights
steps.narration: Patterns in your data reveal opportunities. What's missing? What could be better? Your insights guide what to build. Data without insight is just noise.

steps.title: Build the Solution
steps.narration: Now you build! Use Cursor and AI to create something that addresses the problem. Iterate‚Äîbuild a first version, test it, then improve. Real solutions evolve.

steps.title: Choose Your Problem
steps.narration: Pick one problem to solve. It should be real‚Äîsomething you've actually observed. Specific‚Äînot too broad. And solvable‚Äîsomething you can actually address with a tool or resource.

steps.title: Deep Understanding
steps.narration: Use ChatGPT to go six levels deep. Keep asking why about each answer. Document all six levels. This helps you build a better solution because you truly understand the problem.

steps.title: Gather Your Data
steps.narration: What resources or solutions already exist? What do people say about this problem? What specific data would help‚Äîlocations, prices, reviews? Organize everything you find.

steps.title: Build with AI
steps.narration: Use Cursor to build your solution. Describe what you want, explain the problem, list the features. Make it professional and easy to use. Then iterate‚Äîimprove based on what works.

steps.title: Deploy and Test
steps.narration: Put your solution on GitHub Pages so it's live on the internet. Share it with two or three people who might use it. Get their feedback, then make improvements. Real solutions need real users.

steps.title: Your Portfolio
steps.narration: Your portfolio showcases everything you've learned. It includes work from each week plus your capstone project. This is proof that you can solve real problems.

steps.title: Present Your Work
steps.narration: You'll present your capstone to the group. Cover the problem, your research, the data you gathered, demo your solution, and share what you learned. Keep it short‚Äîthree to five minutes.

steps.title: Show, Don't Tell
steps.narration: Demo your actual project. Let them see it work. Quality over quantity. Be proud‚Äîyou built something real. That's something most people never do.

steps.title: You're a Builder Now
steps.narration: Congratulations! You've completed the academy. You're not just a consumer of technology anymore. You're a builder. You're a problem solver. The world needs more people like you.

steps.title: Keep Going
steps.narration: This is just the beginning. Keep building, stay curious, help others, and level up. The best time to start solving problems was yesterday. The second best time is right now. You have the skills‚Äînow go use them!

questions.question: What's the first step in the problem-solving process?
options: Jump straight to building a solution
Ask deep questions to understand the problem
Copy what others have done
Wait for someone to tell you what to do
questions.explanation: Understanding comes before building. Go six levels deep with questions to truly understand the root causes before designing a solution.

questions.question: Why do we gather data before building?
options: To make the project take longer
Data isn't really necessary
To find patterns and insights that guide what to build
To impress our teachers
questions.explanation: Data reveals patterns and opportunities. Without insights from data, you might build the wrong thing. Data without insight is just noise.

questions.question: What's the relationship between insight and building?
options: They're not related
Insights guide what to build‚Äîthey show what's missing or could be better
Building comes first, insights come later
You only need one or the other
questions.explanation: Insights from your data guide what to build. They reveal what's missing, what could be better, and where opportunities exist.

questions.question: What makes a good capstone problem?
options: It should be as broad as possible, like 'fix education'
It should be real, specific, and solvable
It should be something nobody has ever thought of
It should require no research
questions.explanation: Good capstone problems are real (actually observed), specific (not too broad), and solvable (you can address them with a tool or resource).

questions.question: Why go six levels deep on your capstone problem?
options: To waste time before building
Because six is a lucky number
To truly understand root causes and build a better solution
Teachers require it
questions.explanation: Going six levels deep helps you understand the real root causes. This leads to a better solution because you're addressing the actual problem, not just symptoms.

questions.question: After building your first version, what should you do?
options: Consider it done and move on
Delete it and start over
Test it, get feedback, and make improvements
Hide it from everyone
questions.explanation: Real solutions evolve through iteration. Share with 2-3 potential users, get their feedback, and improve based on what works and what's confusing.

questions.question: What should your capstone presentation include?
options: Just show the code
The problem, research, data, demo of solution, and what you learned
Only talk about what went wrong
Read directly from a script for 30 minutes
questions.explanation: A good presentation covers the problem, your research (6 levels deep), data and patterns you found, a demo of your solution, and what you learned.

questions.question: What does 'show, don't tell' mean for your presentation?
options: Use lots of words on your slides
Demo your actual project and let them see it work
Don't speak at all
Only use pictures
questions.explanation: Instead of just describing your project, demo it! Let the audience see it actually work. A working demo is more powerful than any description.

questions.question: After completing this academy, what are you now?
options: Just another student
A consumer of technology
A builder and problem solver
Someone who needs to wait for permission
questions.explanation: You're not just a consumer anymore‚Äîyou're a builder and a problem solver. You have skills most adults don't have. The world needs more people like you!
